Re-denomination is another weird thing that you can only do to fiat money. In 2006, the value of the Zimbabwean dollar was multiplied by 1.000, meaning that something that cost a $1000 note would the next moment cost $1. But since they had serious hyperinflation going on - at it's peak 79.6 BILLION percent per month - in 2008 they did the same trick but this time multiplied by 10.000.000.000. And again early 2009 by 1.000.000.000.000, just weeks after release of the $100 trillion bank note. A few months later they finally abandoned the currency because, as you could probably guess, this situation was hopeless. Fiat money is weird...

I know its been 7 years, but technically Michael makes a mistake at 3:28. When the central bank wants to increase money supply, they buy government bonds from a NON-BANK counterparty. That way, whoever they buy the bonds from will deposit money at a bank, hey-presto, more money. If the counterparty is a bank you run the risk that they are recapitalising after a financial crisis (i.e. exactly what happened after 2008), thus any money you create will go to the banks' capital and won't affect money supply.

A couple of years ago somebody estimated that the derivatives were 160 trillion USD in value. So the very rich (mostly banks and trading houses) bet on the real economy to the tune of 250 trillion (derivatives plus stock market and commodities), which likely is larger than the real economy.

Gold is also valuable only because people believe it's valuable. There are metals that are more rare and more difficult to extract than gold, but aren't valued as exchange tokens. That suggests a fallacy in thinking. Nothing has intrinsic value, only use value (what I can make with it) or exchange value (whether exchanging for money or goods).

Fiat money is therefore no less real than eg gold. The value of gold is actually more easily manipulated than a stock market index. Single industry indexes can be manipulated easily by eg Trump telling he's levying sanctions against China (it would be nice to have a short position on industries that are dependent upon free trade with China), or when he then later tells without any evidence that he's got this great deal with China (now you'd do well to have a long position--I'm not saying that Trump children knew beforehand about those announcements, but research suggests that they've been very "lucky" with their stock trades until the crash now in the last few weeks).

Sorry Vsauce, the value of Fiat Money does not depend on our beliefs. If the Government says you need to pay them $10, or they are going to put you in jail, you will work to get those $10 regardless of what you believe about the value of those dollars. I.e. those ten dollars will have clear value for you, regardless what you believe (assuming you don't want to go to jail).



This shows you where the value of fiat money comes from - taxes. The Federal Government doesn't tax in order to get the money to spend (that is ridiculous - they create USD). Taxes are what give value to their otherwise valueless pieces of paper.



And the banks of virtually no country use the Fractional Reserve system. That's one of the biggest misconceptions of our age. When someone takes out a loan, there is a simple asset exchange. The bank gives you bank credit (bank money, credit to your deposit account) in exchange for your IOU - which is a valuable asset as long as you have good credit. They don't need any reserves of anything in order to do this. It is simply an exchange of IOUs.



Finally you make a big deal about what would happen if Canada invaded us - as if that is supposed to show that commodity money is somehow better than fiat money. Well if Canada invaded us, they could just as well confiscate all our gold. So that doesn't show anything. Meanwhile, every country has abandoned gold because commodity money severely restricts the productive capacity of an economy.

Value of fiat depends on all other commodities, as they are as close as you can get to “money” though in form of a real good, and usually the most basic of finished goods.

You’ll notice the “belief” happens by consequence to rarity and availability. If money comes and goes rapidly, it’s less precious and prices rise until the velocity normalizes and resets at higher price. So, spending on itself is the action that leads to arriving at a value .
Usually the first transaction every done in the whole universe of money spending economies has zero sensibility in how either party arrives at the price or decides the exchange... this would mean even the person spending that money would have had to never even worked for it but rather picked it up somewhere. Because of he worked for it and earned it, then he would be the first transaction ever... his time and effort for the money. So it is but through only a series of transaction we can arrive at what money is worth and it is because of a universe filled with other real, physical things we can purpose.

Why does this matter? Because economically, he who controls the currency, also controls the price. Money should never be replicated or creates. It should be fixed. Which is why a healthy economic system doesn’t just rely on a stable monetary base, it is impossible to have an economy without one.
Soon, our national debt will consume our “printing” to where we will see this first hand.
This is why we often find advocates for gold and silver.
They cannot be created or destroyed as elements. They can only be lost and found. This neither adds nor subtracts what’s available in the world, and the effort required to extract it often deters many people from going after it. It’s easier to stay fat and work in accounting. :)

“Fiat” is more accurately translated as “let it be so” i.e. make it exist. The word was used to translate the first command of God in genesis, “fiat lux” i.e. “let there be light”, so it makes sense to describe a currency the same way; one could ask “is this really real money?” But term fiat is implies: “The authorities say let it be so” that is, let it be real money. It is commanded into existence.

So back when I watched this I bought into it. But I gotta say Michael is wrong about Fiat money. It's value isn't derived from belief but from the fact that US dollars are the only accepted form of payment for taxes. So in order to pay your taxes you (and everyone) needs this now valuable paper cash inorder to pay your taxes and not go to prison. So it now has value and it's also something you have to aquire so it also becomes ultimately the most convenient medium of exchange. This theory of money has existed since things like the Roman empire where freshly conquered lands adopted the Roman currency because they had to pay taxes to their new government.

Well, the thing giving the US Dollar so much weight in US society is the fact that we are forced to pay our taxes with dollars.  And I do believe that it is illegal (I may be wrong) to exchange gold for groceries or pay an employee in silver within US borders.  What gives the US Dollar weight on a global scale is the fact that in order to buy oil from Saudi Arabia and its allies you need to pay them in US Dollars.  This sort of makes the US Dollar oil backed on a global stage.  You want Oil?  You need US Dollars to get it.  A quick way to fix this is to have your countries currency backed by the value of the US Dollar - which a lot of global economies in the 1st world are backed by now.

I have watched this video a few times since M0 is interesting and other videos regarding the topic often get removed from youtube.... Also I'm not a money expert but i've never really agreed with the idea that the bank is 'creating money' by giving out a loan.. Because that person who took out the loan typically has to pay that money back... The money used to pay back that loaned money basically has to be money printed/at least earned.. Money isn't really born by a bank giving out a loan... Same when someone writes a check money still has to be transferred at some point.. Reflecting on the 5:10 section on video. Also want to watch the mind field series but hate the idea of youtube red. I study history etc and honestly the banking crisis issues I feel are most certainly related to this ideal I typed out here. And interest makes everything even more complicated because its almost like you have to pay back money that 'doesn't exist' because nothing was 'created'. The interest is typically how the banks profit. So instead of 5 coins the banks will get 6 or 10 coins because of interest. Plus there are a few people who together own more money together then entire civilizations/multiple large towns put together. So point being money is sooooo tough to get even-though its sooo 'fake' and that what is being calculated as whats circulating, isn't circulating as much as what is calculated.. Not trying to 'be cheap' or fight against bitcoin/printing money. Printed/digital money is cool and a necessity.

"nothing (could be done) to make a commodity like gold less valuable". 12:15 mark. nonsense. why is the washington monument capped with a 100oz pure aluminum pyramid? because at the time of the monument's construction, aluminum was way more valuable than gold. it was intended to symbolize wealth. but new mining techniques (i.e., something someone did that no one had previously considered) have since made it so abundant that its market value per ounce has plummeted. gold is no different. new mining techniques is all it takes to trash gold's status as a valuable commodity. we know where there's a shitload of it...so the writing is one the wall. no commodity is free from having its value assaulted and in a dramatic way. fiat money has intrinsic vulnerabilities as does any commodity.

With the given example Michael cant actually spend all 5 of his pounds unless he demands Kevin pay back the loan immediately. Otherwise it is the equivalent of a bank run like during the depression days. In practice, if he wanted to withdraw all 5 pounds, the other 3£ would come from the deposits of fellow account holders. And since loans get paid back regularly the reserve should be restored for such small withdrawals soon enough by someone's loan payment. Larger withdrawals cause an overdraft with the central bank that loans new cash made out of thin air and loaned to branch banks at the fed's famous interest rate.

Fiat money's value wouldn't necessarily be erased by invading Canadians though. In principle, it could still be used so long as others would accept it and others would accept it so long as they believe they'll be able to use it to gain the things they want. So if Canadians invaded and took over America and there was a resistance group that used the now untraced dollars to fund its campaigns to reinstate America, maybe it could. After all, the mere promise that money could be valuable again could cause people to want to accept it. It would certainly become a less dependable currency, but my point being is that no amount of authority or public pronouncements can simply erase its value.

Fiat money is actually backed by taxes and the force behind collecting them. When new fiat cash is created, the equivalent amount of future taxes are also created, so the money will eventually be turned in to pay those taxes. This does mean if a government collapses and no longer collects taxes, the fiat could disappear, but in reality, foreign bondholders still can collect on the liability. That's what the concept of "legal tender public and private" is. Critical is the tender for public debt. If a money supply is constrained too far, the public can therefore confiscate on non-money such as real property or even whisky (ie the US Whisky rebellion).

M0 is only used by the UK to calculate all of their currency in sirculation. Many different countries use different meanings such as USA uses M1, M2. The UK uses M0 and M4. where the Eurozone uses. M1,M2 and M3. see below:

• In the US, the two measures of money supply are M1 and M2.
M1, the narrowest measure, covers most liquid forms of money: currency, demand deposits and
other deposits where cheques can be written against.
M2, the broadest measure, is defined as M1 plus savings accounts, time deposits of less than
$100,000 and balances in retail money market mutual funds.
• In the eurozone, the ECB definitions of euro-area monetary aggregates are M1, M2 and M3.
M1 (narrow money) includes currency in circulation and overnight deposits.
M2 (intermediate money), comprises M1 plus deposits with agreed maturities up to two years,
and deposits redeemable at notice of up to three months.
M3 (broad money) comprises M2 plus repo agreements, money market funds and debt
securities of up to two years.
• In the UK, several measures of the money supply have been defined and redefined, and two
measures remain: M0 and M4.
M0, the monetary base, is the narrowest measure of the two in that it only contains notes and
coins in circulation and banks’ operational deposits at the Bank of England – the UK’s central
bank.
M4, the broadest measure, is defined as M0 plus bank and building society deposits.

Fiat money has value because a government decides that they will only collect taxes from their citizens in that currency.

The value of the American dollar is in the fact that it can be used to pay taxes to the government of the USA. Thus, this is why Americans want to sell things for American dollars and not for another currency such as the Euro.

This also why a currency's strength and rate of exchange can give clues to how strong an economy is or how stable and trustworthy the issuing government is.

Fiat money doesn't have intrinsic value, but the value it does have doesn't simply come from the flat decree of a central bank but rather the fact that the issuing government will continue to exist and provide its citizens with services in exchange for taxes (in that currency).

There may be anew 'gold standard' coming this way. It is still fiat (faith) but the faith backing is the legal system that enforces the repayment of debt and the accuracy and availability of national statistics for National Average Earnings, NAE. For example: The contract will simply say, "Mr A lent Mr B $300. The capital value will rise at the rate of increase of NAE to offset the falling value of money. A fee of additional interest on the money will be payable on the money owed. The rate of repayments will be anything agreed between the parties. During hyper-inflation payments can be suspended." That is it. The NAE owed at that point freezes at the number of NAE still owed. Given legal backing the NAE attracts interest, unlike gold, and the supply is unlimited. Anyone can sign such contracts.

VMike is truly amazing, but I think that he could have expanded further on the fiat money explanation. For example, it may not carry value per se, however, it carries the confidence as a (relatively) reliable medium of value transaction. That is, for the work that I do (value) I can use money as a means to exchange it for another kind of value (like buying food). So it is an agreed upon means of exchanging actual value. The depreciation of fiat money comes if too much of it is printed, while abolishing it entirely simply means that another means of exchanging your work for another's would require a different medium (like another currency, or quid pro quo).

12:29 Actually, this isn't technically true. The value of certain commodities such as precious metals and gemstones absolutely can be (and often are) controlled through a notion called artificial scarcity, wherein the bulk of the supply of certain commodities is sequestered from public circulation to artificially inflate its value. For example, the reason diamonds are so expensive (aside from ridiculous jewelry store markups,) is not because they are rare (they really aren't,) but because diamond mining corporations such as the DeBeers Group have a huge portion of the world's diamonds locked away in secure vaults, essentially controlling the world's diamond supply and making them artificially rare. If DeBeers and other prominent diamond mining groups were to suddenly unleash the entire world's diamond supply to the market, even the Hope Diamond, a 45.52 carat rock valued at $350 million dollars, would become as valuable as a glass replica.

Actually, there is a way to make gold less rare, we just haven't developed it yet.  Gold is a long term byproduct of fusion.  Alien invaders who were capable of triggering supernovae or using fusion to directly manufacture heavy elements from lighter ones beyond the payoff point (anything heavier than iron takes more energy to make than it gives off) could wage economic warfare on a gold based economy by increasing the gold supply.

That said, if they wanted to pick a fight with us (which is kinda silly - consider Loki's comment in the Avengers movie about ants and boots), they'd have more direct means of pulling this off.

Also, fiat money can last after the fall of the power that established it.  If the US government were to fall into anarchy, it would probably take some time for the citizens to get used to the idea that cash has no actual value, and, by collectively agreeing that it has value, said value would be preserved.  (How long this takes would probably depend on how capitalist-fixated the country in question is)

If you deposit £5 in the bank, and someone borrows 3, you are unable to spend your full £5.  Attempting to do so will result in this bank going bankrupt leaving you ... if you're lucky, £3 down; but more likely, once creditors and lawyers have taken their share, somewhat worse off.
The only time you don't end up in a worse position is if an outside source - say that central bank or some form of sale of shares  - steps in, and provides more money to the bank, allowing you to obtain your £5.

It's fun how some species barter and others don't.
Spiders have been around for over 400mil year and yet they haven't even invented a form of trade-off for something as crucial for the survival of theirs species, like mating. Spiders aren't even the only species, where the female kill and eats the male for a surplus of nutrition for their egg-laying. You'd think that by now- (unless some species do) the males would bring some form of gift- or offering to their mate, to negate the risk of being killed and eaten, like a spider male could catch a few big, still-living flies, nicely wrapped up and present them to the female and be like "Hey! I'll give you these, if you promise not to eat me.".
For a moment, I though that in spiders case, they have no self-conscience and therefore no care for their own survival, but that was debunked quickly, when I remembered how some male spiders leave behind an emergency string of web, to bungee-jump to safety after mating, saving their own lives, but thereby cheating the female of her meal to help with the production of eggs... why would they develop this risky and usually not successful solution, rather than for example, barter for their life with freshly caught prey — commodity money, in a literally sense.

The bond market of a country or a currency can have a reverse tinker bell affect (or a stock or an investment commodity). If too many people believe in it they will hoard it and the value will rise. In the case of fiat money the CB will create more money. But eventually people may realize that so much of this money was created the value will drop because of supply and demand. 

The housing bubble would be another example. So many people believed houses would go up in price every year that they did just that for a long time. Until people found out they couldn't afford to pay for those houses.

Your example of Canada making the US Dollar not fiat money is incorrect, as oil is the biggest commodity to be purchased with US dollars and as such, it's highly accepted by countries dealing with oil and US dollars. It's been discussed that if the fiat money of the US dollar is to be challenged it would be done by China of the BRICS Bank by increasing the value of the Chinese currency and declare that the removal of the Chinese government's need to hold US debt, thus devalued the US dollar to the point of no return.

It's strange to think about this... The Tinkerbell effect. A weird example is fear. When your friend tells you a scary story, you might be scared. When you are in pitch blackness, you cannot see what is around you. You don't know what exactly is around you anymore, so you draw conclusions from things that aren't true for example "there is something scary in the darkness". The more you believe that there is something scary in the darkness the more afraid you become. In other words the more you think something might be scary, the more scary it is... In that case what is fear? Why do we experience fear at all if it is merely a figment of our imagination? I therefore conclude that people with less imagination are the people who are brave. People who don't believe in much might find it hard to be afraid of darkness. In that case are people who are called "pussies" and are left out of social groups are actually the people with more personality?..

Sort of an interesting fact specific to the United States' creation of currency.
The creation of money isn't necessarily purchased by local banks from the Federal Reserve, it is in fact BORROWED on a LOAN. This doesn't necessarily sound like a bad thing but in reality it is.
Lets say the LB (local bank) "purchases" money from the FR (federal reserve) of $1, that money isn't in fact "purchased" it is actually loaned, and like every loan, interest is added on as well. That means the bank must eventually pay back the $1 plus (lets just say) 90C. But here's the catch, in order to pay back the 90C it must be created by the FR, thus creating an infinite loop where more and more interest is added on, throwing the US into debt that can NEVER be payed off.
Here's a scary reality though, the Federal Reserve Bank isn't actually Government owned, it is a private company...

Interesting, but he repeats the fallacy that gold is a commodity.  It really only has fiat value.  Think about it - we have far more than we need, something like 80% of gold is hoarded (as coins or bullion).  That gold is not used in industry or even for jewelry (jewelry is the next biggest use).  You can't drink it, eat it, fertilize your crops with it, or make better clothes or housing with it.  

It only has the value that it does because we all believe it is still rare and that somebody else will buy it from us for at least as much as we paid for it.

Despite the 26b cap BitCoin has, LiteCoin has a much higher cap, making it a prime candidate for this sort of world destruction through declining money value.

You can contribute to global financial ruin. Here's how;

Investing in digital currencies like BitCoin and LiteCoin are a good way to have peer-to-peer, anonymous money exchange. But if enough services that accept BitCoin and LiteCoin exist to convert these into multiple currencies, then in theory, through combined arbitrage, enough fiat currency can be "Created" to make inflation skyrocket, and make everything expensive. The implications of global inflation are huge and, at worse, devastating.

Fiat money doesn't derive it's value solely by fiat (odd as that may sound), it derives its value in part from the fact that the state accepts it in payment of tax. Imagine you run a business and you were paid by your customers in gold, but had to pay your tax in £ or $. You'd have to sell some of your gold for £ or $ to pay your tax with, hence creating a constant demand for £ and $. So fiat money is actually backed by its acceptability as payment of tax liabilities.

(7) The ability to have incorrect moral views is actually an argument that morality is objective because if it was subjective, then no one could be wrong! Morality would be just whatever you think it is for you. The sentence "For me, stealing is okay" would actually make sense, and you woudl be wrong to try to stop that person from stealing.

(6) While we're okay letting people have their views about Jello and act upon them, we do not have the "whatever floats your boat" attitude about moral things.
Someone who steals can't just say, "Hey, leave me alone. I think it's okay. Keep your opinions to yourself." Because we don't think it's a matter of opinion. We think it's a matter of fact that stealing is actually, legitimately wrong.

(5) (forgot the 4) Something that's truly subjective is like the Jello example I used earlier. I dislike Jello. You love it. And we're both just fine to have those views. Neither is right nor wrong. It's subjective, and it would be really silly to bicker about it. Let everyone have their own tastes.
But we think act very differently about morality. We DEFEND our position, make arguments for it, and we are not okay with people acting immorally against one another.

Our views do differ on some moral issues, some more than others, but we all still have this sense that someone else is mistaken - that's it's possible to be wrong about morality. Think of an ethical issue that you feel strongly about on one side or another. Homosexuality, abortion, whatever it is. You think the other side's view is wrong. They're mistaken. It's not just that their view is different like and you happen to dislike it. You really think they're mistaken and should think differently.

(3) And that is a really interesting question, too. Is it that fact that it harms someone? No, because we think it's okay to harm someone in self-defense. Well is it because it harms someone who's innocent? That's closer, but still an incomplete explanation.
Back to your question, I don't know if it's totally accurate to say that everyone's personal moral standards are subjective, depending on what you meant by that.

(2) Murder is truly, objectively wrong. Our collective intuitions got that one right. Most moral philosophers think this way - that our intuitions are reliable on the big issues. On smaller things, like the nitty-gritty details of the scenario you presented me with a few days ago, our intuitions are harder to figure out and sometimes considered less trustworthy.
But the issue has always been not whether murder is wrong, but WHY murder is wrong. What is the wrongness-making quality of murder?

That's actually an interesting question. For thousands of years as philosophers have debated moral issues, one sub-issue is what constitutes evidence. Is our moral instinct actually evidence? i.e. do our moral feelings actually tell us what's moral?
Most philosophers think that our moral intuitions DO tell us about real morality on at least the very biggest, most basic issues. For example, pretty much everyone's intuition says that murder is bad. And we think that's accurate.

(7) Sorry for ranting. I'm done now haha

(6) Again, however, even if we got everyone's moralities (including our own) to lineup perfectly with real morality, that would not solve the world's problems. Case in point: me. Even on thing that I'm sure about, like the fact that it's good to love your neighbor, I still fall short. Right moral beliefs do not have a strong causal relationship with right moral behavior. Behavior flows much moreso out of what a person loves. If I love myself more than I love you, my behavior will show that. Etc.

(5) That's why it makes sense to have moral discussions. We're all trying to line up our personal moralities with reality. If morality was not objective, it seems to me, there would be no point in arguing about the ethics of euthanasia or abortion or sweatshops - because there would be no actual answer to be had. But I think we want our personal moralities to line up with actual morality, and we want other people's personal moralities to line up, too, for everyone's sake. That's why we debate it

(4) Also, even if my own personal moral views were perfectly accurate to real morality, that would not mean that I am a morally good person. I can (and do, often) act differently than my own moral views say a person should. I think we should love our neighbors, yet I find in myself a lot of indifference toward people. That's bad.

(3) If I tried to stop him without harming him but in the end had to kill him, that'd be a whole different thing. I think that whatever the answer is in any of those situations, it's objectively true - an actual, real standard against which all people will be judged and about which people can be mistaken, such that majority view doesn't dictate it. I don't claim that my moral views are all perfect and objectively true, but only that morality is objective.

(2) If you have made legitimate arguments that I have overlooked, forgive me. And please point them out to me again.

I can see that you have already categorized me and made a bunch of assumptions about me to make it easier to dismiss my points. Apparently, it would take too much effort to think about my points critically and engage me in productive discussion. Well, if you change your mind, the offer remains on the table.

I'm not an expert in sociology or economics, and I never claimed to be, but I do have a strong interest in them. (I'm a graduate student in cognitive science.)

(#5) I want to clarify what I meant by the implication that we're not morally good people. I do not mean that we're not awesome. People are really freakin' cool. Human life is precious (objectively ;), not just because majority thinks so) and beautiful and good. But morally, we've got some problems.

(#3) And that's what I believe is the switch. You see my belief in objective morality as a fabrication to escape the discomfort of subjectivism. But I think the opposite - that is, I think that some people believe in subjective morality because they prefer it over the idea of being wrong. Because let's face it. If there's an objective morality, everyone is wrong. We've all broken the rules. We break 'em all the freakin' time. And we dislike like the idea of an authority higher than ourselves.

The consequences will be huge ... it is like having a tsunami, earthquake and hurricane all in one go.

Definition of 'Lender Of Last Resort'
An institution, usually a country's central bank, that offers loans to banks or other eligible institutions that are experiencing financial difficulty or are considered highly risky or near collapse. In the U.S. the Federal Reserve acts as the lender of last resort to institutions that do not have any other means of borrowing and whose failure to obtain credit would dramatically affect the economy.

When you go over the list of countries that bought US loans, you will be for a big surprised, apart from China, Japan, UK  (largest loaners)... there are a list of third world nations who are loaning monies to US.

I think it's to do with the way our body attempts to regulate temperature. As we use our muscles etc., we give off heat, which, if we give off too much, can damage our organs. Gold isn't intrinsically valuable. It's a commodity in the layman's sense of the word, but it's not valuable in and of itself. Rather, it's valuable because people everywhere will take it - people believe that it is.

A good way to test if something is intrinsically valuable is to imagine a world in which only that thing exists, in this example, gold. And then ask, is it a good world? If the answer is no, the thing is not intrinsically valuable.

SO you keep interchanging the terms "money" and "currency." Currency is (1) a medium of exchange (2) durable (3) unit of account (4) divisible (5) portable and (6) fungible. In money creation, the central bank just acts like a regular customer of the bank and deposits money there (sometimes in other forms). The bank can then lend out 90% of that money, and keeps 10% as a fractional reserve.

Stupid? A lot of thought actually went into the name and symbol. The symbol (£) comes from the letter L, which stands for libra which is a unit of weight in the roman empire. The Ps meant Pesos, which is Spanish for "weights". Also the word dollar came from the ward daler (German for taller).

I think it's sort of fallacious to refer to fiat money as any less intrinsically valuable than gold. Gold is valuable because it's rare, and fiat money is also - the only difference is that with fiat money, the rarity is imposed by a government. Just as you could destroy the value of fiat money by making people stop believing in it, so too could the value of gold be destroyed if people stopped believing it has value. Humans evolved through 2 processes: Mutation and Selection. 

Mutation is what 'adds new genes' to the pool. A random gene gets mutated into a new one. For example through radiation. Or more common: Through a translation error when it's copied.

Selection determines which genes stay and which get 'bred out' (actually, they die out). If a gene causes you to be more likely to reproduce before you die, it becomes more common. If not, it becomes less common.

It is a common misconception that Fractional Reserve Banking only benefits the bank.
Facts: Most banks loan out about 90% of the money people deposited. If they wouldn't, they could only give out loans untill their start capital was gone, practically nothing.
Implications: Because of this system, people starting a business, building a factory or buying a house can get a loan. This creates more wealth and, in time, it benefits everyone.
Risks: If everyone wanted their money now we have a problem.

No, it is genuinely an error as I have been told by YouTube officials. This is why it always appears to stay at 301, not 300. And yes, the way the coding is set out allows for views to be delivered simultaneously if there are 299 on the view count. If two people are watching a video, it will jump to 302 and then the check for 300 is made. Since it's above 300, the counter stops there. Because of the gate used, the server actually lets in an additional view when 300 is reached, thus achieving 301

It's not an error. It's the way the program is written. It is written so that if someone views a video and the current view count is less than OR EQUAL TO 300, then the view is added to the count without being verified. Therefore, if you watch a video and it already has 300 views before you view it, the view count is EQUAL TO 300, so you're view is added, making it 301. The reason it might stick on 302 or 303 is because sometimes, multiple views report at the same moment, when view count = 300
